title: Is the set of non-negative real numbers a complete set or not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Take any Cauchy sequence . As  is a complete set .But , i.e. every Cauchy sequence from  has a limit in (2.) is important because for example  is not complete: take . It is a Cauchy sequence, but it does not converge to anything in

The entire set of real numbers is complete — there are no gaps between any two numbers. edited to say:Thanks to Dr. Alexey Godin, I now realize that the non-negative reals do not (entirely, reliably) have the completeness property. Oops!
